title: Centre tells Twitter, YouTube to block links of BBC documentary about 2002 Gujarat riots
content:
The Union government has directed YouTube and Twitter to remove links to the BBCâ€™s documentary revisiting Prime Minister Narendra Modiâ€™s role in the 2002 Gujarat riots.The first part of the documentary, released on January 17, alleged that Modi â€“ then the chief minister of Gujarat â€“ prevented the police from acting to prevent the violence. The Indian government, however, alleged that the film pushed a discredited narrative.The documentary, titled India: The Modi Question, has not been officially released in India. However, pirated versions of it have been circulating on social media platforms.The Ministry has invoked emergency powers under the Information Technology Rules to direct social media platforms to take down the links. Twitter has been ordered to block over 50 posts containing YouTube videos of the documentary.Both Twitter and YouTube have complied with the directive, Kanchan Gupta, senior advisor with the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting said.Senior officials from the ministries of external affairs, home and information and broadcasting examined the documentary and concluded that it was an attempt to cast aspersions on the Supreme Courtâ€™s authority.A closure report by a Special Investigation Team appointed by the Supreme Court to inquire into the violence said in February 2012 that there was no prosecutable evidence against Modi and 63 others.On June 24 last year, the Supreme Court dismissed a petition by Zakia Jafri, the wife of Congress leader Ehsan Jafri, challenging the SIT report. Ehsan Jafri was among the 69 people who were killed when a mob went on a rampage in Ahmedabadâ€™s Gulberg Society on February 28, 2002, pelting stones and setting fire to homes.  The officials from the Centre also concluded that the documentary was found to be â€œundermining sovereignty and integrity of India, and having the potential to adversely impact Indiaâ€™s friendly relations with foreign statesâ€, Gupta said.The senior advisor described the film as â€œhostile propaganda and anti-India garbage, disguised as documentaryâ€.ImportantVideos sharing @BBCWorld hostile propaganda and anti-India garbage, disguised as â€˜documentaryâ€™, on @YouTube and tweets sharing links to the BBC documentary have been blocked under Indiaâ€™s sovereign laws and rules.n1â€” Kanchan Gupta ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡³ (@KanchanGupta) January 21, 2023

The first part of the  documentary claimed that a team sent by the British government to inquire into the riots said that Modi, who was then the stateâ€™s chief minister, was â€œdirectly responsible for a climate of impunityâ€ that led to the violence.The documentary cited a report that the inquiry team had sent the United Kingdom government to say that â€œreliable contactsâ€ stated that Modi met senior police officers on February 27, 2002, and â€œordered them not to interveneâ€ in the rioting.In February and March 2002, large-scale communal violence erupted across Gujarat after the coach of the Sabarmati Express train returning from Ayodhya was allegedly burned by a mob in Godhra.
